HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Andrew is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history, significant for depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension. He presents today with an upper respiratory infection. He reports that he began to feel tired and short of breath after yard work and heavy lifting. He endorses feeling warm but is not sure if he has a fever. He denies seasonal allergies, and also reports being fully vaccinated for Covid-19. He mentions that his elbows and knees were in pain after the strenuous activity.

As far as his chronic conditions, Mr. Andrew reports that his depression has been managed well without medication. He has been attending barre classes for relaxation. He monitors his blood sugar levels and blood pressure regularly, except on the weekends. His diet has been controlled, although there have been some deviations during house parties. He assures that his medications for hypertension have been taken regularly.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No definite fever, but patient reports feeling warm. Positive fatigue.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath during strenuous activity. No cough or phlegm yet.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive joint pain in elbows and knees after lifting heavy items.
• Neurological: No complaints.
• Psychiatric: Denies worsening of depressive symptoms.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Respiratory: Scattered ronchi bilaterally on lung exam, clears with cough.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
• Musculoskeletal: No edema in the lower extremities, but pain to palpation of elbows bilaterally.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Within normal limits.
Hemoglobin A1c: Elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Andrew is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension. He presents with an upper respiratory infection that seems to be viral in nature. 

Upper Respiratory Infection.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has symptoms of a viral syndrome.
• Diagnostic Testing: Send for a Covid-19 test just to rule it out.
• Medical Treatment: Advise the patient to take Robitussin for the cough and Ibuprofen or Tylenol for fever. 

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been managing well without medication.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management. Consider starting medication or psychotherapy if needed in the future. 

Diabetes Type II.
• Medical Reasoning: Recent hemoglobin A1c was elevated.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 4 months. Continue to monitor blood glucose levels at home.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports blood pressure has been under control and he's been adhering to the medication regimen.
• Additional Testing: Order lipid panel.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20mg daily. Provided a refill for the patient.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. Follow-up appointment to be scheduled in about four months.

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux, who presents today for her annual exam. It has been about a year since I last saw the patient.

The patient reports her arthritis has greatly improved. She has taken up walking, exercising, and doing yoga, and this constant movement has significantly helped alleviate her joint pain. She reports no recent flare ups or stiffness and confirms her compliance with her weekly dose of methotrexate.

Regarding her atrial fibrillation, the patient endorses continued palpitations, the most recent episode being a week ago. Stress seems to be a trigger for these episodes. The patient has tried meditation and running with her dog as stress management strategies but finds them ineffective.

The patient's reflux seems well managed. She has cut out soda from her diet and is taking protonix, which appears to be effective. She reports no flare ups in over five months.

She denies any chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, or vomiting. She reports some nasal congestion due to allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses palpitations. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting. 
• Musculoskeletal: Denies recent joint pain or stiffness.
• Respiratory: Endorses nasal congestion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. 
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur appreciated. Regular rate and rhythm.
• Musculoskeletal: Right elbow shows edema and erythema. Pain to palpation. No lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Autoimmune panel is within normal limits.

Event monitor shows patient going in and out of atrial fibrillation with conversion pauses.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Andrea is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux, who presents today for her annual exam.

Rheumatoid Arthritis:
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well and has remained active since her last visit. Her autoimmune panel is normal, showing good control of her arthritis with methotrexate.
• Medical Treatment: Continue methotrexate 2.5 mg once weekly. Refill provided.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised her to continue her exercise regimen. If necessary, referral to rheumatology can be provided.

Atrial Fibrillation:
• Medical Reasoning: Her palpitations persist and her event monitor reveals she has been in and out of atrial fibrillation with conversion pauses.
• Additional Testing: Refer to cardiology for cardiac ablation.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to her the potential benefits of a cardiac ablation procedure for her atrial fibrillation.

Reflux:
• Medical Reasoning: Her reflux symptoms are well controlled on protonix and dietary modifications.
• Medical Treatment: Continue protonix 40 mg once daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with dietary modifications and to inform me if she has any issues with her reflux.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

Emergency room follow-up for hyperglycemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Albert is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant. He presents today for emergency room follow-up after an episode of hyperglycemia over the weekend. Albert reported feeling "woozy" over the weekend and had been not monitoring his blood sugar levels due to family circumstances. His mother was in the hospital, leading to less control over his diet. However, since the emergency room visit, Albert has resumed following his diet.

Regarding his kidney transplant, Albert reported compliance with his immunotherapy medications and had no new complaints. His kidney function has been stable according to a visit with Dr. Reyes three weeks ago. 

Albert's depression has been manageable despite some challenges over the past year and a half. Albert reported finding time to relax in the afternoons and has recently started practicing meditation, which he found helpful. He has chosen to refrain from additional therapy at this time.

The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and dizziness.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Neurological: Denies lightheadedness and dizziness.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.
• Endocrine: Endorses diabetes.
• Renal: Endorses kidney transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur noted (known past finding).
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Musculoskeletal: 1+ edema to the lower extremities.
• General: Patient not in distress.

RESULTS

• Non-fasting glucose is elevated at 162.
• Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Albert is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant, presenting today for emergency room follow-up due to a recent episode of hyperglycemia.

Type 2 Diabetes
• Medical Reasoning: His blood sugar was elevated over the weekend and has been inconsistently high. His hemoglobin A1c level was also high at 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lantus to 20 units at night and continue to monitor blood glucose levels. 
• Additional Testing: Order repeat hemoglobin A1c in a couple of months.

Depression
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has managed his depression with relaxation techniques and recently started meditation, which has helped him. 
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management and monitor. The patient will contact the clinic if his condition worsens.

Kidney Transplant
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's kidney function has been stable and he has been compliant with his immunosuppression medications.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen and follow-up with Dr. Reyes for management of immunosuppression medications.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. He will return for follow-up and lab work as recommended.

Right distal radius strain and contusion.

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. We will treat the injury conservatively. I recommended icing the affected area and taking an anti-inflammatory. Left shoulder and elbow pain following a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Jose James is a pleasant 65-year-old male, a new patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of constant pain in his left shoulder and elbow which began approximately five months ago. He experienced a fall while ascending stairs in icy conditions and landed on his left side, especially his shoulder and elbow.

The patient is an active gym-goer, usually weightlifting two days a week. However, the pain in his shoulder and elbow has prevented him from lifting more than 15-20 pounds. The pain seems to worsen during and after his workouts, resulting in him taking a break from the gym for the past 1-2 weeks. He continues to keep active by walking 30 minutes daily with his wife.

His pain management strategy has included some icing and resting the affected areas. He has not taken any medication for the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling sensation in the area.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Mr. James is retired from an office job. He used to regularly engage in weightlifting at the gym but has stopped due to his current condition. He maintains a regular walking routine with his wife.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK:
Examination of the left shoulder: Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer's test. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median radial ulnar sensation. Abduction to 90 degrees. No warmth, erythema, or deformity noted.
Examination of the left elbow: Tenderness present, no warmth, erythema, or deformity noted.

ASSESSMENT

Impingement syndrome of the left shoulder.

PLAN

After a thorough examination and discussion with Mr. James, the initial plan of care includes starting physical therapy, with two sessions per week recommended. Home exercises provided by the physical therapist are to be followed as well. He is advised to continue icing the affected area and ensure rest. The patient has been informed to contact the clinic if his symptoms worsen or fail to improve with therapy.

As a next step if physical therapy does not alleviate symptoms, a cortisone injection was discussed. Mr. James has agreed to this approach, expressing preference to try physical therapy first before considering an injection.

A referral to Dr. Martha Rivera for physical therapy has been requested. Mr. James will be contacted within the next day or two for scheduling.

The patient has been experiencing a runny nose, cough, irritability, pulling on his ears, and a low-grade fever. There is also worsening cradle cap.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient is almost three years old and has a known history of cradle cap.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient's older sister has been ill recently, and the patient has also had exposure to a nephew with a diagnosed sinus infection.

MEDICATIONS

The patient's guardian reports administering saline mist for nasal symptoms, Tylenol for the fever, and baby Vick's applied to his feet for breathing. A humidifier has also been used to aid in breathing.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports irritability and low-grade fever of 100.3 F.
ENT: Reports runny nose, non-barky cough, and ear tugging.
Gastrointestinal: Decreased appetite noted, with less intake from the bottle and refusal to eat cereal.

VITALS

Temperature: 100.3 degrees F.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: Observations of patient's actions suggest irritability and discomfort.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Nose: Clear nasal discharge reported.
- Examination of Ears: Patient has been seen pulling at his ears. No abnormalities observed during the physical examination.
- Examination of Throat: Not reported.

Respiratory
- The patient has a non-barky cough.

Skin
- Cradle cap has worsened, observed on the scalp.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Upper respiratory symptoms.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has experienced runny nose, non-barky cough, ear pulling, and a low-grade fever since last night, likely due to a viral infection, possibly contracted from a recent play date with a child diagnosed with a sinus infection.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The guardian has been advised to maintain fluid intake, rest, and watch for a more severe, barky cough. If this develops, the patient should be given half a teaspoon of his sister's medicine. If symptoms do not worsen, a follow-up is scheduled in one week.

- Medical Treatment: No additional treatment provided at this time.

Kayla Ward, a pleasant 16-year-old female, accompanied by her mother, presents today for an evaluation of facial acne that started about two years ago. She has been using over the counter treatments including regular facial washing and Persa-Gel, which provides moderate relief. The acne is mostly located on her face, with no associated symptoms of itching, bleeding, or pain. There is no significant medical history. 

PAST HISTORY

Medical
No significant medical history reported.

Surgical
No surgeries reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient lives with her parents and sister, in a pet-friendly home with a dog, bird, and bunnies. She is in the 7th grade and plays basketball, volleyball, and tap. She uses sunscreen in the summer, SPF 30. No reported family history of skin conditions.

MEDICATIONS

Over-the-counter Persa-Gel.

ALLERGIES

No known drug allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Dermatological: Multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities. Scattered skin colored papules. Open and closed comedones, and erythematous papules on the face, primarily on the forehead and also on the central cheeks and chin. The chest and back are relatively spared.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Kayla presents with mild to moderate acne, primarily comodonal with a small inflammatory component. No significant worrisome skin findings. The plan is to start a new skin care regimen: in the morning, she will wash her face with a mild cleanser and use a noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher. In the evening, she will wash her face with the same cleanser, apply a thin layer of adapalene 0.1% cream to acne-prone areas (few nights per week to start, eventually daily), apply Clean and Clear Persa-Gel in a thin layer, and finish with a noncomedogenic moisturizer. She is advised to use sunscreen regularly due to the potential photosensitivity from the topical retinoid. She will return for follow-up in six months to evaluate the response to therapy, and has been instructed to contact the office if she has any questions or concerns before her next visit.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

The patient is on Propranolol for migraines. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient reports a family history of breast cancer, her mother was diagnosed at age 40. She has been recommended to start mammograms at age 30 but has not yet started as she is currently 27. There have been recent weight changes with a loss of 10 pounds over the past few months. The patient does not have any children currently but has plans for the future. She does not have any history of tobacco or illicit drug use and consumes alcohol occasionally.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Breasts
Bilateral heavy breasts with bra strap indentations noted on the shoulders. One breast was slightly lower than the other.

ASSESSMENT

Julia Jones is a 27-year-old female presenting with symptoms of macromastia, including back pain, neck pain, and shoulder pain which is affecting her daily activities. After a thorough discussion regarding the risks and benefits of the procedure, the patient appears to be an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty.

PLAN

- Take photos for insurance submission.
- Document symptoms for insurance submission.
- Await switch in insurance from Blue Cross Blue Shield to the new plan her husband is getting.
- Once new insurance is in place, submit documentation and photos for approval.
- If approved, schedule surgery and preoperative consultation.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is instructed to notify the office as soon as the insurance switch is completed. In the meantime, the patient is advised to continue with her current pain management strategies and to report any worsening or new symptoms immediately.
